questions.modified_sentence: A diagnosis of Bipolar I Disorder requires at least one manic episode lasting a minimum of seven consecutive days, which must include elevated or irritable mood along with at least four additional symptoms, such as excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences.
phrases: A diagnosis of Bipolar I Disorder requires at least one manic episode
lasting a minimum of seven consecutive days, which must include elevated or irritable mood
along with at least four additional symptoms,
such as excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences.
questions.explanation: According to the DSM-5 criteria for a manic episode in Bipolar I Disorder, the individual must display elevated, expansive, or irritable mood plus at least three additional symptoms (or four if the mood is only irritable). The passage incorrectly states 'four' as the general minimum. When mood is elevated or expansive, only three additional symptoms are required. The number four applies specifically to cases where the mood disturbance is exclusively irritable rather than elevated or expansive.

questions.modified_sentence: Cluster A personality disorders, which include Paranoid, Schizoid, and Schizotypal types, are characterized by odd or eccentric behavior and are genetically linked to bipolar disorder.
phrases: Cluster A personality disorders,
which include Paranoid, Schizoid, and Schizotypal types,
are characterized by odd or eccentric behavior
and are genetically linked to bipolar disorder.
questions.error_original: and are genetically linked to bipolar disorder
questions.error_correct: and are genetically linked to schizophrenia
questions.explanation: Cluster A personality disorders (Paranoid, Schizoid, and Schizotypal) are genetically linked to schizophrenia, not bipolar disorder. Research has consistently shown a higher prevalence of Cluster A personality disorders among biological relatives of individuals with schizophrenia, reflecting shared genetic vulnerability.

questions.modified_sentence: Features include preoccupation with details/rules/order, perfectionism interfering with task completion, excessive devotion to work, over-conscientiousness about morality, inability to discard worn-out objects, reluctance to delegate, generous spending style, and rigidity/stubbornness.
phrases: Features include preoccupation with details/rules/order,
perfectionism interfering with task completion, excessive devotion to work,
over-conscientiousness about morality, inability to discard worn-out objects, reluctance to delegate, generous spending style, and rigidity/stubbornness.
questions.explanation: OCPD is characterized by a miserly spending style, where money is hoarded and viewed as something to be saved for future catastrophes. The passage incorrectly states 'generous spending style,' which is the opposite of the actual DSM-5 diagnostic criterion for OCPD. Individuals with OCPD adopt a miserly approach to spending on both themselves and others.

questions.modified_sentence: Trichotillomania is frequently comorbid with excoriation (skin-picking) disorder, OCD, major depressive disorder, and other anxiety disorders, and co-occurrence with excoriation disorder is particularly common, reflecting the shared classification as impulse-control disorders.
phrases: Trichotillomania is frequently comorbid with excoriation (skin-picking) disorder, OCD, major depressive disorder, and other anxiety disorders,
and co-occurrence with excoriation disorder is particularly common,
reflecting the shared classification as impulse-control disorders.
questions.explanation: Trichotillomania and excoriation disorder are classified together as body-focused repetitive behavior (BFRB) disorders, not as impulse-control disorders. While trichotillomania was previously categorized under impulse-control disorders in earlier editions of the DSM, in DSM-5 both trichotillomania and excoriation disorder are placed under Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders, and their shared classification is specifically as body-focused repetitive behavior disorders.

questions.modified_sentence: Bipolar I requires at least one manic episode, and while depressive episodes are commonly observed they are not a diagnostic requirement, distinguishing it from Bipolar II which requires at least one hypomanic episode and one major depressive episode.
phrases: Bipolar I requires at least one manic episode,
and while depressive episodes are commonly observed they are not a diagnostic requirement,
distinguishing it from Bipolar II which requires at least one hypomanic episode
and one major depressive episode.
questions.error_correct: at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode (both required)
questions.explanation: Wait — let me reconsider. The sentence as constructed actually states both requirements across phrases 2–3. Let me provide a genuinely erroneous version.

questions.modified_sentence: Benzodiazepines are effective for acute anxiety relief but are not recommended as first-line treatment due to risk of dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal, and they are considered a primary pharmacological option for OCD.
phrases: Benzodiazepines are effective for acute anxiety relief
but are not recommended as first-line treatment due to risk of dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal,
and they are considered a primary pharmacological option for OCD.
questions.error_original: and they are considered a primary pharmacological option for OCD
questions.error_correct: and they do not treat OCD
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines are not effective for treating OCD. They are useful for acute anxiety relief but have no established efficacy for obsessive-compulsive disorder. First-line pharmacotherapy for OCD typically involves SSRIs or clomipramine, not benzodiazepines.

questions.modified_sentence: For children with CU traits, standard punishment-based approaches are less effective because these children show reduced sensitivity to punishment cues, and Dadds et al. (2012) demonstrated that targeting emotion regulation and behavioral compliance through parent-mediated interventions can improve outcomes for children with CU traits.
phrases: For children with CU traits, standard punishment-based approaches are less effective
because these children show reduced sensitivity to punishment cues,
and Dadds et al. (2012) demonstrated that targeting emotion regulation and behavioral compliance
through parent-mediated interventions can improve outcomes for children with CU traits.
questions.error_original: targeting emotion regulation and behavioral compliance
questions.explanation: Dadds et al. (2012) specifically demonstrated the effectiveness of targeting emotion recognition and empathy in children with callous-unemotional (CU) traits, not emotion regulation and behavioral compliance. The intervention focused on improving these children's ability to recognize emotions in others and develop empathy, which are core deficits associated with CU traits.

questions.modified_sentence: DSM-5 made several important changes to AN criteria: removed the specific BMI threshold and the word "refusal" to eat, replacing it with "avoidance"; removed the amenorrhea criterion, recognizing that AN occurs in males and post-menopausal women; and Criterion B no longer requires explicit acknowledgment of fear of weight gain -- persistent behavior interfering with weight gain suffices.
phrases: DSM-5 made several important changes to AN criteria: removed the specific BMI threshold and the word "refusal" to eat,
replacing it with "avoidance"; removed the amenorrhea criterion,
recognizing that AN occurs in males and post-menopausal women;
and Criterion B no longer requires explicit acknowledgment of fear of weight gain -- persistent behavior interfering with weight gain suffices.
questions.explanation: DSM-5 replaced the word 'refusal' in the Anorexia Nervosa criteria with 'restriction' (as in 'restriction of energy intake'), not 'avoidance.' The term 'restriction' reflects the behavioral pattern of limiting food intake relative to requirements, leading to significantly low body weight. 'Avoidance' is associated with Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID), a separate diagnosis.

questions.modified_sentence: SSRIs such as fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, citalopram, and escitalopram are considered first-line treatment for depression, selectively blocking dopamine reuptake, and are generally well tolerated with side effects including sexual dysfunction, GI symptoms, and initial anxiety.
phrases: SSRIs such as fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, citalopram, and escitalopram
are considered first-line treatment for depression, selectively blocking dopamine reuptake,
and are generally well tolerated with side effects including sexual dysfunction,
GI symptoms, and initial anxiety.
questions.explanation: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors) work by selectively blocking the reuptake of serotonin, not dopamine. The name SSRI itself indicates their mechanism of action targets serotonin. Dopamine reuptake inhibition is the mechanism associated with other classes of medications, such as bupropion (an NDRI).

questions.modified_sentence: Withdrawal is defined as the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance, or the substance is taken to relieve or avoid tolerance symptoms, and this constitutes one of the two pharmacological criteria in the DSM-5 substance use disorder diagnosis.
phrases: Withdrawal is defined as the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance,
or the substance is taken to relieve or avoid tolerance symptoms,
and this constitutes one of the two pharmacological criteria
in the DSM-5 substance use disorder diagnosis.
questions.explanation: According to DSM-5 Criterion 11 for Substance Use Disorders, withdrawal is defined as either experiencing the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance OR taking the substance to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms — not tolerance symptoms. Tolerance (Criterion 10) is a separate pharmacological criterion involving needing increased amounts of the substance or experiencing diminished effects with continued use of the same amount.

questions.modified_sentence: Hoarding disorder is a standalone DSM-5 diagnosis distinct from OCD, where hoarding in HD is ego-dystonic (valued) rather than ego-syntonic as seen in OCD, and CBT with motivational interviewing is considered the first-line treatment approach.
phrases: Hoarding disorder is a standalone DSM-5 diagnosis distinct from OCD,
where hoarding in HD is ego-dystonic (valued) rather than ego-syntonic as seen in OCD,
and CBT with motivational interviewing is considered the first-line treatment approach.
questions.error_original: hoarding in HD is ego-dystonic (valued) rather than ego-syntonic
questions.error_correct: hoarding in HD is ego-syntonic (valued) rather than ego-dystonic
questions.explanation: In Hoarding Disorder (HD), the hoarding behavior is ego-syntonic, meaning the individual values and does not want to give up the possessions. This contrasts with OCD, where obsessions and compulsions are ego-dystonic (experienced as unwanted and distressing). The passage swapped these two terms: ego-dystonic was incorrectly paired with '(valued)' and attributed to HD, when it should be ego-syntonic that is valued and characteristic of HD.

questions.section: Overview of Depressive and Bipolar Disorders
questions.modified_sentence: This reorganization reflects growing evidence that bipolar disorders are more closely related to anxiety spectrum disorders in terms of genetics, symptomatology, and neurobiology, and mood disorders collectively represent one of the leading causes of disability worldwide.
phrases: This reorganization reflects growing evidence
that bipolar disorders are more closely related to anxiety spectrum disorders
in terms of genetics, symptomatology, and neurobiology,
and mood disorders collectively represent one of the leading causes of disability worldwide.
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 reorganization placed bipolar disorders in a separate chapter because research showed they are more closely related to schizophrenia spectrum disorders (not anxiety spectrum disorders) in terms of genetics, symptomatology, and neurobiology. This was a key rationale for the structural change from DSM-IV to DSM-5.

questions.modified_sentence: With impairment in written expression which encompasses dysgraphia, the specific areas affected include spelling accuracy, grammar and punctuation accuracy, and clarity or organization of oral expression.
phrases: With impairment in written expression which encompasses dysgraphia,
the specific areas affected include spelling accuracy,
grammar and punctuation accuracy,
and clarity or organization of oral expression.
questions.error_original: clarity or organization of oral expression
questions.error_correct: clarity or organization of written expression
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 specifier 'With impairment in written expression' refers to difficulties in the clarity and organization of written expression, not oral expression. The three areas specified are spelling accuracy, grammar and punctuation accuracy, and clarity or organization of written expression. Oral expression difficulties fall under a different category of communication disorders.

questions.modified_sentence: Duration of action is 30-90 minutes, which is often shorter than the duration of action of the opioid itself — therefore, repeated doses may be necessary to prevent recurrence of cardiovascular depression.
phrases: Duration of action is 30-90 minutes,
which is often shorter than the duration of action of the opioid itself —
therefore, repeated doses may be necessary
to prevent recurrence of cardiovascular depression.
questions.explanation: Naloxone (Narcan) is administered to reverse opioid overdose, and the primary life-threatening symptom it addresses is respiratory depression, not cardiovascular depression. Opioids suppress the brainstem respiratory centers, and naloxone's repeated dosing is specifically necessary to prevent the recurrence of respiratory depression as the opioid may outlast naloxone's 30-90 minute duration of action.

questions.section: Criterion A: Exposure to Traumatic Event
questions.modified_sentence: Under DSM-5 PTSD Criterion A, learning that a traumatic event occurred to a close family member or close friend qualifies as indirect exposure, but in cases involving death of the family member or friend, the event must have been violent or unexpected.
phrases: Under DSM-5 PTSD Criterion A,
learning that a traumatic event occurred to a close family member or close friend qualifies as indirect exposure,
but in cases involving death of the family member or friend,
the event must have been violent or unexpected.
questions.error_original: the event must have been violent or unexpected.
questions.error_correct: the event must have been violent or accidental.
questions.explanation: According to DSM-5 PTSD Criterion A3, when the traumatic event involves the death of a close family member or close friend, the death must have been 'violent or accidental' — not 'violent or unexpected.' The term 'accidental' is the specific wording used in the DSM-5, distinguishing it from deaths due to natural causes. 'Unexpected' is not the correct qualifier in this criterion.

questions.modified_sentence: DSM-5 renamed this from "gender identity disorder" to emphasize that gender nonconformity is not itself a disorder -- the clinical problem is the anxiety that may accompany it.
phrases: DSM-5 renamed this from "gender identity disorder"
to emphasize that gender nonconformity is not itself a disorder --
the clinical problem is the anxiety that may accompany it.
questions.explanation: The passage states that the clinical problem is the distress, specifically dysphoria, that may accompany gender nonconformity. The term 'anxiety' is incorrect here. The DSM-5 specifically uses the term 'dysphoria' (meaning distress or unease) rather than 'anxiety,' and the very name of the diagnosis -- Gender Dysphoria -- reflects this emphasis on distress, not anxiety, as the core clinical concern.

questions.modified_sentence: In the DSM-5, Separation Anxiety Disorder requires persistent and excessive fear of or reluctance about being alone or without major attachment figures, and symptoms must be present for at least six weeks in children and adolescents, and six months or more in adults.
phrases: In the DSM-5, Separation Anxiety Disorder requires persistent and excessive fear of
or reluctance about being alone or without major attachment figures,
and symptoms must be present for at least six weeks in children and adolescents,
and six months or more in adults.
questions.explanation: According to the DSM-5, Separation Anxiety Disorder symptoms must persist for at least four weeks in children and adolescents (not six weeks). The duration requirement for adults is six months or more. Confusing these two duration thresholds is a common error.

questions.modified_sentence: Research shows that gender dysphoria in childhood persists into adulthood in approximately 40-60% of cases, but persistence rates are much higher when dysphoria intensifies during adolescence.
phrases: Research shows that gender dysphoria in childhood
persists into adulthood in approximately 40-60% of cases,
but persistence rates are much higher
when dysphoria intensifies during adolescence.
questions.explanation: The persistence rate of childhood gender dysphoria into adulthood is approximately 12-27%, not 40-60%. Research consistently indicates that the majority of children with gender dysphoria do not continue to experience it into adulthood, though persistence rates are notably higher when dysphoria intensifies or emerges during adolescence. The 40-60% figure significantly overstates the childhood persistence rate.

questions.modified_sentence: Criterion C for Anorexia Nervosa includes disturbance in the way body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight or shape on self-esteem, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight.
phrases: Criterion C for Anorexia Nervosa includes disturbance in the way body weight or shape is experienced,
undue influence of body weight or shape on self-esteem,
or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness
of the current low body weight.
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 Criterion C for Anorexia Nervosa specifies 'undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation,' not 'self-esteem.' The term 'self-evaluation' is the precise language used in the diagnostic criteria, referring to how one judges or appraises oneself, which is a broader construct than self-esteem. This distinction matters clinically because self-evaluation encompasses cognitive appraisal processes beyond just feelings of worth.

questions.modified_sentence: Despite the name similarity, only about 23-32% of individuals with OCD also have OCPD, and OCPD is the most prevalent personality disorder in the general population at approximately 8-15%.
phrases: Despite the name similarity,
only about 23-32% of individuals with OCD also have OCPD,
and OCPD is the most prevalent personality disorder in the general population at approximately 8-15%.
questions.explanation: The passage states that OCPD has a prevalence rate of approximately 3-8% in the general population. The error inflates this to 8-15%, which is significantly higher than the established epidemiological estimate for OCPD.

questions.modified_sentence: Schizophreniform Disorder lasts 1 month to less than 6 months, while Schizophrenia requires 6 months or more including prodromal or residual symptoms, with at least 2 weeks of active-phase symptoms.
phrases: Schizophreniform Disorder lasts 1 month to less than 6 months,
while Schizophrenia requires 6 months or more including prodromal or residual symptoms,
with at least 2 weeks of active-phase symptoms.
questions.error_original: at least 2 weeks of active-phase symptoms
questions.error_correct: at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms
questions.explanation: According to the DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Schizophrenia, the 6-month duration must include at least 1 month (not 2 weeks) of active-phase symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech). The '2 weeks' figure is a distractor; it does not apply to the active-phase symptom requirement for Schizophrenia.

questions.modified_sentence: According to DSM-5, Pica is characterized by the persistent eating of nonnutritive or nonfood substances over a period of at least one month, the eating behavior must be developmentally inappropriate for individuals at a developmental level of at least four years, and the behavior is not part of a culturally sanctioned or socially normative practice.
phrases: According to DSM-5, Pica is characterized by the persistent eating of nonnutritive or nonfood substances over a period of at least one month,
the eating behavior must be developmentally inappropriate for individuals at a developmental level of at least four years,
and the behavior is not part of a culturally sanctioned or socially normative practice.
questions.error_original: at a developmental level of at least four years
questions.error_correct: at a developmental level of at least two years
questions.explanation: According to the DSM-5, the Pica diagnosis specifies that the eating of nonnutritive substances must be developmentally inappropriate for individuals at a developmental level of at least 2 years, not 4 years. This threshold reflects the fact that mouthing and ingesting nonfood objects is considered normal in children under 2 years of age.

questions.modified_sentence: The posttraumatic model views DID as arising from severe childhood trauma (typically severe physical/sexual abuse before age 5), with dissociation serving as a defense mechanism.
phrases: The posttraumatic model views DID as arising from severe childhood trauma
(typically severe physical/sexual abuse before age 5),
with dissociation serving as a defense mechanism.
questions.explanation: The posttraumatic model of DID specifies that the severe childhood trauma (physical/sexual abuse) typically occurs before age 9, not before age 5. The age threshold of 9 is significant because it aligns with developmental periods during which identity consolidation is still occurring, making the child vulnerable to dissociative fragmentation as a defense against overwhelming trauma.

questions.modified_sentence: Wernicke's encephalopathy results from thiamine deficiency and is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, while Korsakoff's syndrome is primarily characterized by retrograde amnesia and confabulation.
phrases: Wernicke's encephalopathy results from thiamine deficiency
and is characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia,
while Korsakoff's syndrome is primarily characterized by retrograde amnesia and confabulation.
questions.explanation: Korsakoff's syndrome is primarily characterized by anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories), not retrograde amnesia. While some retrograde amnesia may be present, the hallmark feature of Korsakoff's syndrome is anterograde amnesia along with confabulation, resulting from chronic thiamine deficiency typically associated with prolonged alcohol use.

questions.modified_sentence: In the DSM-5 substance use disorder criteria, Criteria 8 and 9 fall under the Risky Use cluster, where Criterion 9 refers to continued use despite knowledge of a physical or psychological problem caused or exacerbated by the substance, and together with the other nine criteria they form three broad symptom clusters used to determine severity.
phrases: In the DSM-5 substance use disorder criteria, Criteria 8 and 9 fall under the Risky Use cluster,
where Criterion 9 refers to continued use despite knowledge of a physical or psychological problem caused or exacerbated by the substance,
and together with the other nine criteria they form three broad symptom clusters used to determine severity.
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 substance use disorder criteria are organized into four (not three) broad symptom clusters: Impaired Control (Criteria 1–4), Social Impairment (Criteria 5–7), Risky Use (Criteria 8–9), and Pharmacological Indicators (Criteria 10–11). Stating 'three' omits one of these clusters.

questions.modified_sentence: The black box warning on antidepressants warns of increased suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 18-24) during initial treatment, and the risk is that as mood improves before energy and motivation return, the individual may have increased capacity to act on suicidal thoughts.
phrases: The black box warning on antidepressants warns of increased suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 18-24) during initial treatment,
and the risk is that as mood improves before energy and motivation return,
the individual may have increased capacity
to act on suicidal thoughts.
questions.error_original: as mood improves before energy and motivation return
questions.error_correct: as energy and motivation return before mood improves
questions.explanation: The passage states that the risk arises because energy and motivation return before mood improves, giving the patient increased capacity to act on pre-existing suicidal thoughts. The error reverses this sequence, incorrectly stating that mood improves before energy and motivation return. The clinically important point is that the return of energy and motivation while mood remains depressed creates a dangerous window during early antidepressant treatment.

questions.modified_sentence: The dopamine hypothesis is supported by the correlation between antipsychotic efficacy and D2 receptor blockade, and the observation that dopamine antagonists such as amphetamines can induce psychotic symptoms in healthy individuals.
phrases: The dopamine hypothesis is supported by the correlation between antipsychotic efficacy and D2 receptor blockade,
and the observation that dopamine antagonists such as amphetamines
can induce psychotic symptoms in healthy individuals.
questions.explanation: Amphetamines are dopamine agonists, not antagonists. They increase dopamine activity, which can induce psychotic symptoms and thereby support the dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia. Dopamine antagonists (such as antipsychotics) reduce psychotic symptoms by blocking D2 receptors.

questions.modified_sentence: The NICE guidelines recommend stepped care: (1) low-intensity CBT including ERP for mild OCD, (2) higher-intensity CBT with ERP or SSRI for moderate OCD, (3) combined CBT/ERP plus SSRI for severe OCD, and (4) clomipramine or augmentation with a benzodiazepine for treatment-resistant cases.
phrases: The NICE guidelines recommend stepped care: (1) low-intensity CBT including ERP for mild OCD,
(2) higher-intensity CBT with ERP or SSRI for moderate OCD,
(3) combined CBT/ERP plus SSRI for severe OCD,
and (4) clomipramine or augmentation with a benzodiazepine for treatment-resistant cases.
questions.explanation: The NICE guidelines for treatment-resistant OCD recommend augmentation with an antipsychotic (such as a low-dose atypical antipsychotic like risperidone or aripiprazole), not a benzodiazepine. Benzodiazepines are not recommended as augmentation agents for treatment-resistant OCD in stepped care guidelines.

questions.modified_sentence: Prolonged Grief Disorder was introduced in the DSM-5-TR and requires that the bereaved individual experience at least 3 of 8 specified symptoms most days, to a clinically significant degree, for a minimum of 6 months following the death in adults.
phrases: Prolonged Grief Disorder was introduced in the DSM-5-TR
and requires that the bereaved individual experience at least 3 of 8 specified symptoms most days,
to a clinically significant degree, for a minimum of 6 months following the death in adults.
questions.error_original: for a minimum of 6 months following the death
questions.error_correct: for a minimum of 12 months following the death
questions.explanation: The DSM-5-TR specifies that for adults, the grief reaction in Prolonged Grief Disorder must persist for at least 12 months following the death of a close person. The 6-month duration threshold applies to children and adolescents, not adults. This is a critical diagnostic distinction in the DSM-5-TR criteria for Prolonged Grief Disorder.

questions.modified_sentence: Gambling disorder is the first non-substance behavioral addiction included in DSM-5, requiring 4 or more of 9 criteria to be met within a 6-month period.
phrases: Gambling disorder is the first non-substance behavioral addiction included in DSM-5,
requiring 4 or more of 9 criteria
to be met within a 6-month period.
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Gambling Disorder require that 4 or more of 9 criteria be met within a 12-month period, not a 6-month period. The 6-month timeframe is associated with other disorders but not Gambling Disorder.

questions.modified_sentence: Non-stimulant options include atomoxetine (Strattera, a serotonin reuptake inhibitor), guanfacine and clonidine (alpha-2 agonists), and bupropion (off-label).
phrases: Non-stimulant options include atomoxetine
(Strattera, a serotonin reuptake inhibitor),
guanfacine and clonidine (alpha-2 agonists), and bupropion (off-label).
questions.explanation: Atomoxetine (Strattera) is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI), not a serotonin reuptake inhibitor. It works by selectively inhibiting the presynaptic norepinephrine transporter, which is its primary mechanism of action in treating ADHD. This distinction is clinically important because its noradrenergic mechanism differentiates it from SSRIs and SNRIs.

questions.modified_sentence: Linehan's (1993) biosocial theory proposes that BPD arises from the transaction between biological vulnerability to emotional dysregulation and an invalidating environment, and Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) targets emotion regulation, distress tolerance, interpersonal effectiveness, and mindfulness, while Kernberg's object relations approach emphasizes projection as the primary defense mechanism in BPD.
phrases: Linehan's (1993) biosocial theory proposes that BPD arises from the transaction between biological vulnerability to emotional dysregulation and an invalidating environment,
and Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) targets emotion regulation, distress tolerance, interpersonal effectiveness, and mindfulness,
while Kernberg's object relations approach emphasizes projection as the primary defense mechanism in BPD.
questions.error_original: emphasizes projection as the primary defense mechanism in BPD
questions.error_correct: emphasizes splitting as the primary defense mechanism in BPD
questions.explanation: Kernberg's object relations approach identifies splitting — not projection — as the primary (or principal) defense mechanism in Borderline Personality Disorder. Splitting involves seeing oneself and others as all good or all bad, and it is considered the hallmark primitive defense in BPD according to Kernberg's theory. Projection is a different defense mechanism and is not the one Kernberg specifically highlighted as primary in BPD.

entries.definition: A condition included in the DSM-5's Section III as a topic warranting further research. It involves persistent and recurrent use of the internet to engage in games, leading to clinically significant impairment or distress.

The first and only non-substance behavioral addiction included in the DSM-5, placed in the Neurodevelopmental Disorders chapter. This placement reflects growing evidence that gambling disorder shares significant neurobiological, genetic, and clinical features with substance use disorders.

A substance use disorder in the DSM-5 characterized by a problematic pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress. It is diagnosed on a severity continuum based on the number of criteria met.

A substance use disorder in the DSM-5 involving a problematic pattern of opioid use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress. It includes criteria such as tolerance, withdrawal, and continued use despite negative consequences.

questions.explanation: Gambling Disorder is placed in the Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders chapter of the DSM-5, not the Neurodevelopmental Disorders chapter. This placement was specifically chosen to reflect the shared neurobiological, genetic, and clinical features between gambling disorder and substance use disorders.

entries.definition: Alcohol withdrawal is recognized in the DSM-5 and can occur within hours to days after cessation of prolonged heavy use. Symptoms may include autonomic hyperactivity, hand tremor, insomnia, nausea, psychomotor agitation, anxiety, and in severe cases, grand mal seizures or delirium tremens.

Opioid withdrawal is recognized in the DSM-5 and typically begins within hours to days of cessation of sustained opioid use. Characteristic symptoms include dysphoric mood, nausea or vomiting, muscle aches, lacrimation or rhinorrhea, pupillary dilation, piloerection, sweating, diarrhea, yawning, fever, and insomnia.

Caffeine withdrawal is included in DSM-5 and occurs following abrupt cessation of daily caffeine use. Common symptoms include headache, marked fatigue or drowsiness, dysphoric or depressed mood, difficulty concentrating, and flu-like symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, or muscle pain.

Cannabis withdrawal is an official diagnosis in DSM-5, occurring within approximately 1 week of cessation of heavy use. Symptoms include irritability/anger, nervousness/anxiety, sleep difficulty, increased appetite/weight gain, restlessness, depressed mood, and at least one physical symptom such as abdominal pain, shakiness, sweating, fever, chills, or headache.

questions.explanation: The error reverses the appetite and weight symptom of cannabis withdrawal. DSM-5 lists 'decreased appetite or weight loss' as a withdrawal symptom, not 'increased appetite/weight gain.' This is a notable distinction because cannabis use itself is associated with increased appetite (the 'munchies'), so withdrawal produces the opposite effect — decreased appetite and weight loss.

questions.section: Criterion A: Exposure to Traumatic Event

entries.definition: A trauma-related disorder in the DSM-5 characterized by the presence of nine or more symptoms from five categories (intrusion, negative mood, dissociation, avoidance, and arousal) beginning after a traumatic event and lasting from 3 days to 1 month.

entries.term: Criterion A: Exposure to Traumatic Event
entries.definition: One qualifying pathway for Criterion A in PTSD involves experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details of traumatic events, such as first responders collecting remains. This pathway specifically does not include exposure through electronic media, television, movies, or pictures unless such exposure is recreational in nature.

A dissociative disorder characterized by an inability to recall important autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature, that is inconsistent with ordinary forgetting. It may involve localized, selective, or generalized amnesia.

A dissociative disorder characterized by persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalization (feeling detached from one's own mental processes or body) or derealization (experiencing surroundings as unreal), while reality testing remains intact.

questions.error_original: unless such exposure is recreational in nature
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 Criterion A for PTSD specifies that exposure to aversive details of traumatic events through electronic media, television, movies, or pictures does not count unless the exposure is work-related (e.g., police officers reviewing crime scene footage). The error substitutes 'recreational in nature' for 'work-related,' which reverses the meaning of the exclusion criterion.

entries.definition: An acute neurological condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly associated with chronic alcohol use. It is characterized by a triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. If treated promptly with thiamine, it can be reversed before progressing to more severe damage.

A chronic neurological condition that develops following untreated Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe retrograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation, in which patients fabricate memories to fill gaps. The condition is often irreversible even with treatment.

A progressive cognitive decline caused by prolonged heavy alcohol use that leads to widespread cortical and subcortical brain damage. It involves deficits across multiple cognitive domains including memory, executive function, and visuospatial abilities. Unlike Korsakoff's syndrome, impairment is more global rather than primarily amnestic.

A neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from severe liver dysfunction, often caused by chronic alcohol-related liver disease. It is characterized by confusion, personality changes, and impaired consciousness due to the accumulation of neurotoxins such as ammonia. Treatment focuses on reducing ammonia levels and managing underlying liver disease.

questions.error_original: severe retrograde amnesia (inability to form new memories)
questions.error_correct: severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories)
questions.explanation: Korsakoff's syndrome is primarily characterized by severe anterograde amnesia — the inability to form new memories — not retrograde amnesia. Retrograde amnesia refers to the inability to recall previously formed memories. While some retrograde amnesia may be present in Korsakoff's, the hallmark feature is anterograde amnesia. The error subtly swaps 'anterograde' for 'retrograde,' which are commonly confused memory terms.

entries.definition: A peptide hormone primarily produced by the stomach that stimulates appetite and promotes food intake. Ghrelin levels typically rise before meals and fall after eating, playing a key role in hunger signaling and energy balance.

A hormone produced primarily by adipose tissue that signals satiety and helps regulate long-term energy balance. Leptin levels are disrupted in eating disorders, and these disruptions are widely understood to be primary causes rather than consequences of disordered eating.

A glucocorticoid hormone released by the adrenal cortex in response to stress that influences metabolism, immune function, and appetite. Elevated cortisol levels have been observed in individuals with anorexia nervosa and may contribute to metabolic dysregulation.

A peptide hormone produced by the beta cells of the pancreas that regulates blood glucose levels and influences appetite and fat storage. Insulin dysregulation has been implicated in binge eating patterns and metabolic complications of eating disorders.

questions.error_original: these disruptions are widely understood to be primary causes rather than consequences of disordered eating
questions.error_correct: many of these disruptions appear to be consequences rather than causes of disordered eating
questions.explanation: The passage states that neuroendocrine changes involving leptin, ghrelin, and other appetite-regulating hormones are disrupted in eating disorders, but that many of these changes appear to be consequences rather than causes of disordered eating. The error reverses this relationship, claiming the disruptions are understood as primary causes rather than consequences.

entries.definition: A sudden, brief episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions such as laughter or surprise. It is one of the hallmark features of narcolepsy type 1 and can range from subtle jaw drooping to full postural collapse.

A neurochemical finding central to narcolepsy type 1, confirmed when CSF hypocretin-1 levels fall below 130 pg/mL, which serves as the definitive biomarker. Hypocretin (also called orexin) is a neuropeptide produced in the lateral hypothalamus that plays a key role in regulating wakefulness and REM sleep.

A transient inability to move or speak occurring during the transition between sleep and wakefulness. It is commonly associated with narcolepsy but can also occur in isolation in the general population, and episodes typically last seconds to a few minutes.

Vivid sensory experiences that occur at sleep onset, often visual or auditory in nature, frequently reported by individuals with narcolepsy. They are distinguished from hypnopompic hallucinations, which occur upon awakening rather than at the transition into sleep.

questions.explanation: The definitive biomarker threshold for hypocretin (orexin) deficiency in narcolepsy type 1 is CSF hypocretin-1 levels less than 110 pg/mL, not 130 pg/mL. This specific cutoff value is established in diagnostic criteria and research literature.

entries.definition: A cognitive-behavioral treatment developed by Edna Foa for PTSD that involves repeated imaginal exposure to traumatic memories and in vivo exposure to trauma-related situations that the patient has been avoiding. It typically consists of 8–15 sessions and has strong empirical support for treating PTSD.

A 16-session treatment protocol developed by M. Katherine Shear that combines elements of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure-based techniques. It includes imaginal exposure through revisiting the story of the death, situational exposure to avoided reminders, and work on restoring functioning. CGT has been shown to be more effective than standard interpersonal psychotherapy for prolonged grief.

A manualized cognitive-behavioral treatment developed by Patricia Resick for PTSD that focuses on challenging and modifying maladaptive beliefs related to the trauma. It typically involves 12 sessions and includes written trauma accounts and cognitive restructuring worksheets. CPT has strong empirical support for treating PTSD in both veterans and civilians.

A time-limited psychotherapy originally developed by Gerald Klerman and Myrna Weissman that focuses on improving interpersonal functioning and addressing role disputes, role transitions, grief, and interpersonal deficits. It typically consists of 12–16 sessions and has strong empirical support for treating major depressive disorder.

questions.explanation: The passage states that CGT combines elements of interpersonal therapy (IPT) and exposure-based techniques. The error substitutes 'cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)' for 'interpersonal therapy (IPT).' While CGT does use exposure-based techniques (which are CBT-derived), the foundational therapeutic framework it integrates with those techniques is IPT, not CBT.

entries.definition: A DSM-5 diagnosis characterized by marked delay in, marked infrequency of, or absence of orgasm, or markedly reduced intensity of orgasmic sensations. These symptoms must be present on at least 75-100% of occasions of sexual activity and must persist for a minimum of approximately 6 months.

A DSM-5 diagnosis in males characterized by marked delay in, marked infrequency of, or absence of ejaculation during partnered sexual activity. Symptoms must be experienced on approximately 75-100% of occasions and persist for a minimum of approximately 6 months.

A DSM-5 diagnosis characterized by a persistent pattern of ejaculation occurring during partnered sexual activity within approximately one minute following vaginal penetration and before the individual wishes it. Symptoms must be present for at least 6 months and occur on 75-100% of occasions.

A DSM-5 diagnosis characterized by persistent difficulties with vaginal penetration, marked vulvovaginal or pelvic pain during intercourse, fear or anxiety about pain in anticipation of or during penetration, or tensing of pelvic floor muscles. Symptoms must persist for a minimum of approximately 6 months.

questions.error_original: persist for a minimum of approximately 6 months
questions.error_correct: persist for a minimum of approximately 6 months is correct for Delayed Ejaculation, but Female Orgasmic Disorder also requires 6 months — however, the error is subtle: the actual passage describes the core symptom criteria without the duration, but the definition is actually correct in duration. Let me recorrect.
questions.explanation: Placeholder

questions.section: Alternative DSM-5 Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD)

entries.definition: A purely dimensional approach to personality pathology that eliminates categorical diagnoses entirely, relying solely on trait ratings across five broad domains to characterize dysfunction. This model was adopted as the primary diagnostic system in the ICD-11 for personality disorders.

entries.term: Alternative DSM-5 Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD)
entries.definition: A dimensional-categorical hybrid model presented in Section II of the DSM-5 that proposes two core criteria for personality disorder diagnosis: Criterion A assesses level of personality functioning (identity, self-direction, empathy, intimacy), and Criterion B assesses pathological personality traits across five broad domains.

A dimensional approach that conceptualizes personality disorders as maladaptive variants of the Big Five personality traits (neuroticism, extraversion, openness, agreeableness, conscientiousness). This model has been influential in research but was not formally adopted into the DSM-5.

A scale used within the AMPD framework that rates impairment across four elements—identity, self-direction, empathy, and intimacy—on a continuum from little or no impairment (Level 0) to extreme impairment (Level 4). A moderate level of impairment (Level 2 or greater) is required for a personality disorder diagnosis.

questions.explanation: The Alternative DSM-5 Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD) is presented in Section III of the DSM-5, which contains 'Emerging Measures and Models.' Section II contains the traditional categorical personality disorder diagnoses. This is a subtle but important distinction, as Section III models are considered for further study rather than being the primary diagnostic framework.

questions.section: General Diagnostic Criteria for Personality Disorders

entries.definition: A Cluster A personality disorder characterized by acute discomfort in close relationships, cognitive or perceptual distortions, and eccentricities of behavior. Individuals often display magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences, and odd speech patterns.

An enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture. The pattern must be pervasive and inflexible, with an onset in adolescence or early adulthood, stable over time, and leading to distress or impairment. It must be manifested in three or more areas including cognition, affectivity, interpersonal functioning, and impulse control.

A Cluster B personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, along with marked impulsivity. Symptoms typically begin by early adulthood and include frantic efforts to avoid abandonment and chronic feelings of emptiness.

A Cluster C personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation. Individuals avoid occupational activities involving interpersonal contact due to fears of criticism, disapproval, or rejection.

questions.explanation: The DSM-5 general diagnostic criteria for a personality disorder require the enduring pattern to be manifested in two or more of the following areas: cognition, affectivity, interpersonal functioning, and impulse control. The error changes this threshold to 'three or more areas,' which is incorrect.

entries.definition: A feeding disorder characterized by repeated regurgitation of food over a period of at least one month. The behavior must not be attributable to an associated gastrointestinal or other medical condition such as gastroesophageal reflux or hiatal hernia. If symptoms occur in the context of another mental disorder, they must be severe enough to warrant independent clinical attention.

A feeding disorder characterized by the persistent eating of nonnutritive, nonfood substances over a period of at least one month. The behavior must be inappropriate to the developmental level of the individual and not part of a culturally supported practice. If it occurs in the context of another mental disorder, it must be severe enough to warrant independent clinical attention.

A feeding or eating disturbance manifested by persistent failure to meet appropriate nutritional or energy needs. It is associated with significant weight loss, nutritional deficiency, dependence on enteral feeding or supplements, or marked interference with psychosocial functioning. The disturbance is not better explained by lack of available food or a culturally sanctioned practice.

An eating disorder characterized by restriction of energy intake leading to significantly low body weight relative to age, sex, and developmental trajectory. It involves an intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, along with a disturbance in the way body weight or shape is experienced.

questions.explanation: The DSM-5 specifies that rumination disorder must not be attributable to gastrointestinal conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux or pyloric stenosis. The error substitutes 'hiatal hernia' for 'pyloric stenosis,' which is the actual example listed in the DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for this disorder.

entries.definition: A stress response pattern characterized by intrusive re-experiencing of a traumatic event, emotional numbing, and hyperarousal symptoms that persist for more than one month following exposure to a life-threatening situation.

A DSM-5-TR diagnosis involving preoccupation with thoughts or memories of the deceased, with the specification that in children and adolescents, preoccupation may focus on the consequences of the death rather than the circumstances. This preoccupation must cause significant functional impairment.

A condition listed in the DSM-5 as requiring further study, characterized by persistent yearning for the deceased, intense sorrow, and preoccupation with the deceased or circumstances of the death, lasting at least 12 months in adults.

A DSM-5 diagnosis involving the development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor, occurring within three months of the onset of the stressor and not persisting for more than six months after the stressor has terminated.

questions.explanation: According to the DSM-5-TR diagnostic criteria for Prolonged Grief Disorder, in children and adolescents, preoccupation may focus on the 'circumstances' of the death, not the 'consequences' of the death. This subtle word swap changes the clinical meaning — 'circumstances' refers to how the person died, while 'consequences' would refer to the aftermath or impact of the death.

entries.definition: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by deficits in intellectual functions and adaptive functioning, with onset during the developmental period. The DSM-5 emphasizes adaptive functioning across conceptual, social, and practical domains to determine severity levels.

A neurodevelopmental disorder affecting approximately 5-15% of school-age children that requires academic skills substantially below age expectations, confirmed by both clinical assessment and standardized testing. The DSM-5 does not require an IQ-achievement discrepancy, moving away from the discrepancy model toward a response to accommodation (RTA) approach.

A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development. Symptoms must be present in two or more settings and must have been present prior to age 12.

A group of neurodevelopmental disorders involving persistent difficulties in the acquisition and use of language, speech, or social communication. Subtypes include language disorder, speech sound disorder, childhood-onset fluency disorder, and social communication disorder.

questions.explanation: The error substitutes 'response to accommodation (RTA)' for the correct term 'response to intervention (RTI).' The RTI approach is the model the DSM-5 moved toward when diagnosing Specific Learning Disorder, replacing the older IQ-achievement discrepancy model. RTI involves providing evidence-based interventions and monitoring the student's response to determine whether a learning disorder is present.

entries.definition: Withdrawal from benzodiazepines can be medically dangerous and potentially life-threatening, with symptoms including seizures, severe anxiety, tremors, and possible delirium. Symptoms may emerge days to weeks after cessation depending on the half-life of the specific agent used.

Opioid withdrawal is intensely uncomfortable and potentially life-threatening, similar to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal. Symptoms typically emerge within hours of last use and include dysphoria, nausea, muscle aches, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, pupillary dilation, piloerection, sweating, diarrhea, and insomnia.

Alcohol withdrawal can be medically serious and potentially fatal, with symptoms ranging from tremors, anxiety, and diaphoresis to seizures and delirium tremens. Severe cases require medical monitoring and may be treated with benzodiazepines to prevent life-threatening complications.

Stimulant withdrawal is generally not life-threatening but is characterized by dysphoric mood, fatigue, vivid unpleasant dreams, insomnia or hypersomnia, and increased appetite. Symptoms typically emerge within hours to days after cessation of prolonged heavy use of substances such as amphetamines or cocaine.

questions.error_original: potentially life-threatening, similar to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal
questions.error_correct: generally not life-threatening, unlike alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal
questions.explanation: Opioid withdrawal is intensely uncomfortable but generally NOT life-threatening. This distinguishes it from alcohol and benzodiazepine withdrawal, which CAN be life-threatening due to risks of seizures and delirium. The error changes 'not life-threatening, unlike' to 'potentially life-threatening, similar to,' reversing a critical clinical distinction about the relative danger of different withdrawal syndromes.

entries.definition: Bulimia Nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors such as purging, fasting, or excessive exercise. It is diagnosed when these behaviors occur at least once a week for three months.

Binge Eating Disorder (BED) was first introduced as a full diagnosis in DSM-IV-TR. It involves recurrent episodes of binge eating that are not followed by compensatory behaviors such as purging or excessive exercise, distinguishing it from Bulimia Nervosa.

Anorexia Nervosa is characterized by restriction of energy intake leading to significantly low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a disturbance in self-perceived body shape. It includes restricting and binge-eating/purging subtypes.

Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) involves an eating or feeding disturbance resulting in persistent failure to meet nutritional needs. Unlike Anorexia Nervosa, it is not driven by body image concerns or fear of weight gain.

questions.explanation: Binge Eating Disorder was first introduced as a full diagnosis in the DSM-5, not the DSM-IV-TR. In the DSM-IV, BED was only listed in the appendix as a condition requiring further study. Its elevation to full diagnostic status was one of the notable changes made in the DSM-5.

entries.definition: A condition in the DSM-5 requiring that the death of someone close occurred at least 12 months ago for adults or at least 6 months ago for children/adolescents. The individual must experience intense sorrow or preoccupation with the deceased on more days than not since the death.

A DSM-5-TR diagnosis requiring that the death of someone close occurred at least 18 months ago for adults or at least 6 months ago for children and adolescents. Since the death, the individual has experienced, on more days than not, intense yearning or preoccupation with the deceased.

A DSM-5 diagnosis characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms developing within 3 months of an identifiable stressor. Symptoms must be clinically significant and are not better explained by another mental disorder or normal bereavement.

A DSM-5 diagnosis requiring exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. Symptoms from any of five categories must be present for a duration of 3 days to 1 month after the traumatic event.

questions.error_original: at least 18 months ago for adults
questions.error_correct: at least 12 months ago for adults
questions.explanation: Prolonged Grief Disorder in the DSM-5-TR requires that the death occurred at least 12 months ago for adults (and at least 6 months for children and adolescents). The error changes the adult duration criterion from 12 months to 18 months, which is a subtle but clinically important factual mistake.

entries.definition: A DSM-5 disorder characterized by persistent difficulty discarding possessions, resulting in clutter that compromises living spaces. A key diagnostic criterion requires that the hoarding causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, including maintaining a safe environment for oneself or others.

A DSM-5 disorder characterized by recurrent, intrusive obsessions and/or repetitive compulsions that are time-consuming or cause clinically significant distress. The obsessions or compulsions must cause marked distress, be time-consuming (e.g., more than one hour per day), or significantly interfere with normal functioning.

A DSM-5 disorder involving preoccupation with one or more perceived defects in physical appearance that are not observable to others. The individual must have performed repetitive behaviors or mental acts in response to the appearance concerns at some point during the course of the disorder.

A DSM-5 disorder classified under Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders, characterized by recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions. A key diagnostic criterion (Criterion C) requires that the skin picking causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, including maintaining a stable environment for oneself or others.

questions.error_original: maintaining a stable environment for oneself or others
questions.error_correct: maintaining a safe environment for oneself or others
questions.explanation: The error subtly replaces 'safe' with 'stable.' The phrase 'maintaining a safe environment for oneself or others' is specific to the Hoarding Disorder diagnostic criteria (Criterion D), not Excoriation Disorder. Additionally, the correct wording emphasizes safety of the living environment, which is particularly relevant to hoarding where accumulated possessions can create physical hazards. Excoriation Disorder's impairment criterion does not include this specific language about maintaining a safe environment.

entries.definition: A pervasive pattern of excessive emotionality and attention seeking. Features include discomfort when not the center of attention, inappropriate sexually seductive behavior, shallow and rapidly shifting emotions, use of physical appearance to draw attention, and exaggerated expression of emotion.

A pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Features include grandiose sense of self-importance, preoccupation with fantasies of success/power/beauty, belief in being special, requiring excessive admiration, sense of entitlement, interpersonal exploitation, lack of empathy, envy of others or belief that others are envious, and arrogant behaviors/attitudes. The DSM-5 requires at least seven of these nine criteria to be met for diagnosis.

A pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others occurring since age 15. Features include failure to conform to social norms, deceitfulness, impulsivity, irritability and aggressiveness, reckless disregard for safety of self or others, consistent irresponsibility, and lack of remorse.

A pervasive pattern of instability of interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, along with marked impulsivity. Features include frantic efforts to avoid abandonment, unstable relationships, identity disturbance, impulsivity, recurrent suicidal behavior, affective instability, chronic feelings of emptiness, and inappropriate intense anger.

questions.error_original: requires at least seven of these nine criteria
questions.error_correct: requires at least five of these nine criteria
questions.explanation: The DSM-5 requires that at least five of the nine listed criteria be met for a diagnosis of Narcissistic Personality Disorder, not seven. The error subtly inflates the diagnostic threshold, which could be missed by someone not thoroughly familiar with the specific cutoff values.

entries.definition: Brief episodes of sudden unilateral loss of muscle tone most often triggered by strong emotions such as laughter or joking. It is considered the most specific symptom of narcolepsy and can range from subtle jaw weakness to full body collapse.

Brief episodes of an inability to move or speak that occur during the transition between wakefulness and sleep. It is commonly associated with narcolepsy and can be accompanied by vivid hallucinations, lasting from seconds to a few minutes.

Vivid sensory experiences that occur at the onset of sleep, often visual or auditory in nature. They are frequently reported in individuals with narcolepsy and can be difficult to distinguish from actual perceptions.

A persistent sense of drowsiness and an irresistible need to sleep during waking hours, representing the most common presenting symptom of narcolepsy. It can result in unintended sleep episodes that occur in inappropriate situations.

questions.explanation: Cataplexy involves sudden bilateral (both sides) loss of muscle tone, not unilateral (one-sided). This is a key diagnostic feature: the muscle tone loss affects both sides of the body simultaneously, which distinguishes it from other neurological conditions that may present with unilateral weakness.

entries.definition: A neuroendocrine test that evaluates HPA axis functioning by administering dexamethasone to assess cortisol regulation. Non-suppression of cortisol following dexamethasone administration is associated with depression, though it lacks diagnostic sensitivity.

A neuroendocrine system involving the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and adrenal glands that regulates the body's stress response. Chronic stress leads to sustained activation and elevated cortisol levels, which has been strongly implicated in the pathophysiology of depression.

A glucocorticoid hormone released by the adrenal cortex in response to HPA axis activation during stress. Chronically elevated levels of this hormone have been associated with depressive disorders, hippocampal atrophy, and impaired negative feedback regulation of the stress response.

A peptide hormone released by the hypothalamus that stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete ACTH, initiating the HPA axis cascade. Elevated levels of this hormone in cerebrospinal fluid have been found in individuals with major depression and stress-related disorders.

questions.explanation: The passage states that non-suppression on the dexamethasone suppression test is associated with depression but lacks diagnostic specificity—meaning it is not specific enough to depression (it can occur in other conditions). The error substitutes 'sensitivity' for 'specificity,' which are distinct psychometric properties. Sensitivity refers to correctly identifying those with the condition, while specificity refers to correctly identifying those without it. The DST's main limitation is its lack of specificity, not sensitivity.

entries.definition: The cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuit is the key neural pathway implicated in OCD. It involves the orbitofrontal cortex, putamen, and thalamus, forming a loop that, when dysregulated, contributes to the repetitive thoughts and compulsive behaviors characteristic of the disorder.

The default mode network (DMN) is a large-scale brain network primarily composed of the medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate cortex, and angular gyrus. It is most active during rest and self-referential thought and has been implicated in rumination seen in major depressive disorder.

The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis is a neuroendocrine pathway involving the hypothalamus, anterior pituitary, and adrenal cortex. Dysregulation of this system, leading to elevated cortisol levels, is strongly associated with stress-related disorders such as PTSD and major depression.

The mesolimbic pathway is a dopaminergic circuit that projects from the ventral tegmental area to the nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex. It plays a central role in reward processing and motivation, and its dysregulation is implicated in substance use disorders and schizophrenia.

questions.explanation: The CSTC circuit in OCD involves the orbitofrontal cortex, caudate nucleus, and thalamus — not the putamen. While the putamen is part of the striatum (along with the caudate), it is the caudate nucleus that is specifically implicated in the CSTC loop associated with OCD. This is a subtle error because both structures are basal ganglia components within the striatum.

entries.definition: Gambling disorder is the only recognized behavioral addiction in the DSM-5, included based on decades of evidence showing it parallels substance addiction in clinical presentation, comorbidity, neurobiology, physiology, and treatment response. It is classified in the DSM-5 chapter on Substance-Related and Addictive Disorders.

Internet gaming disorder was placed in DSM-5 Section II ("Emerging Measures and Models") as a condition for further study rather than being included as an official diagnosis. It involves persistent and recurrent online gaming behavior leading to clinically significant impairment or distress.

Substance use disorder in the DSM-5 combines the previous DSM-IV categories of substance abuse and substance dependence into a single diagnosis measured on a continuum of severity. It is diagnosed based on meeting a threshold number of criteria from a list of 11 possible symptoms.

Caffeine use disorder is another condition placed in DSM-5 Section III ("Conditions for Further Study") rather than being recognized as an official diagnosis. It was included for further research due to emerging evidence of problematic caffeine consumption patterns.

questions.explanation: Internet gaming disorder was placed in DSM-5 Section III ('Conditions for Further Study'), not Section II ('Emerging Measures and Models'). Section II contains diagnostic criteria and codes for official diagnoses, while Section III contains conditions requiring additional research before potential inclusion as official diagnoses.

entries.definition: A circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder characterized by a habitual delay in the timing of the major sleep period relative to conventional sleep-wake times. Individuals typically have difficulty falling asleep and waking at socially desired times, often falling asleep in the early morning hours.

A circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder characterized by a pattern of sleep-wake cycles not synchronized to the 24-hour environment. It is most common in blind individuals who lack light input to the pineal gland.

A circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder characterized by a temporally disorganized sleep-wake pattern, with no clear circadian rhythm. Sleep is fragmented into at least three periods throughout the 24-hour day.

A circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder characterized by an advance in the timing of the major sleep period relative to conventional sleep-wake times. Individuals typically fall asleep and wake much earlier than desired.

questions.explanation: The error replaces 'suprachiasmatic nucleus' (SCN) with 'pineal gland.' In Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Type, blind individuals lack photic (light) input to the suprachiasmatic nucleus, which is the master circadian pacemaker located in the hypothalamus. The pineal gland is a related but distinct structure that secretes melatonin; it receives signals from the SCN but is not the structure that directly receives light input for circadian entrainment.

entries.definition: A DSM-5 depressive disorder characterized by symptoms such as marked affective lability, irritability, depressed mood, and anxiety that occur during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. Marked affective lability includes mood swings, feeling suddenly sad or tearful, and increased sensitivity to rejection. Symptoms must be present in most menstrual cycles and cause clinically significant distress.

A DSM-5 bipolar-spectrum disorder involving chronic fluctuating mood disturbance with numerous periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms lasting at least 2 years in adults. The individual must not have been symptom-free for more than 2 months at a time. Symptoms do not meet full criteria for a major depressive or hypomanic episode.

A DSM-5 depressive disorder diagnosed in children characterized by severe recurrent temper outbursts that are grossly out of proportion to the situation. The outbursts occur three or more times per week, and the mood between outbursts is persistently irritable or angry. Onset must be before age 10, and the diagnosis cannot be made before age 6 or after age 18.

A DSM-5 depressive disorder characterized by symptoms such as marked affective lability, irritability, and depressed mood persisting for at least 2 years in adults. Marked affective lability includes mood swings, feeling suddenly sad or tearful, and increased sensitivity to rejection. The individual must not have been without symptoms for more than 2 months during the 2-year period.

questions.error_original: marked affective lability, irritability, and depressed mood persisting for at least 2 years
questions.error_correct: depressed mood accompanied by at least two additional symptoms (e.g., poor appetite, low self-esteem, hopelessness) persisting for at least 2 years
questions.explanation: The definition incorrectly attributes 'marked affective lability' as a characteristic feature of Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia). Marked affective lability (mood swings, feeling suddenly sad or tearful, increased sensitivity to rejection) is actually a criterion of Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD). Persistent Depressive Disorder is characterized by a chronically depressed mood with additional symptoms like poor appetite, insomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, poor concentration, or hopelessness — not marked affective lability.

entries.definition: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline) that work by blocking the reuptake of serotonin in the synaptic cleft. They are considered first-line treatments for major depressive disorder due to their relatively favorable side effect profile.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., phenelzine, tranylcypromine) that require dietary restrictions, specifically a histamine-free diet to avoid hypertensive crisis. They are generally reserved for treatment-resistant depression or atypical depression.

Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., venlafaxine, duloxetine) that block the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. They are used to treat major depressive disorder and may also be effective for chronic pain conditions.

Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline) that block the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine but also affect histamine and acetylcholine receptors. They are effective antidepressants but carry a higher risk of side effects and lethality in overdose.

questions.explanation: The error substitutes 'histamine-free diet' for the correct 'tyramine-free diet.' Patients taking MAOIs must avoid foods high in tyramine (e.g., aged cheeses, cured meats, certain fermented foods) because tyramine can trigger a dangerous hypertensive crisis when MAO is inhibited. Histamine is a different biogenic amine and is not the substance that must be restricted with MAOI use.

entries.definition: A DSM-5 disorder characterized by recurrent, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) that are typically ego-dystonic, meaning they are experienced as unwanted and distressing. Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is considered a first-line behavioral treatment for OCD.

A standalone DSM-5 diagnosis distinct from OCD, characterized by persistent difficulty discarding possessions regardless of their actual value. Hoarding behavior in this disorder is ego-dystonic, meaning it is experienced as unwanted and distressing. CBT with motivational interviewing is the first-line treatment, as standard ERP alone has limited efficacy.

A DSM-5 disorder classified within the obsessive-compulsive and related disorders category, characterized by preoccupation with perceived flaws in physical appearance that are not observable to others. CBT targeting distorted body image beliefs and behavioral avoidance is a primary psychotherapeutic approach.

A DSM-5 disorder classified within the obsessive-compulsive and related disorders category, characterized by recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions and repeated attempts to decrease or stop the behavior. Habit reversal training is a commonly used behavioral intervention for this condition.

questions.error_original: ego-dystonic, meaning it is experienced as unwanted and distressing
questions.error_correct: ego-syntonic, meaning it is experienced as valued and consistent with one's sense of self
questions.explanation: In Hoarding Disorder, the hoarding behavior is ego-syntonic—individuals typically view their possessions as valuable and meaningful, and they do not experience the hoarding itself as unwanted or intrusive. This contrasts with OCD, where symptoms are ego-dystonic (experienced as unwanted and distressing). This ego-syntonic quality is precisely why standard ERP has limited efficacy and motivational interviewing is needed as part of treatment.

entries.definition: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by deficits in intellectual functions and adaptive functioning with onset during the developmental period. In DSM-5, severity level (mild, moderate, severe, profound) is determined primarily by IQ score ranges rather than adaptive functioning across conceptual, social, and practical domains.

A diagnosis reserved for individuals under the age of 5 years when clinical severity level cannot be reliably assessed. It is used when a child fails to meet expected developmental milestones in several areas of intellectual functioning and requires reassessment after a period of time.

A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent difficulties learning keystone academic skills such as reading, writing, or mathematics, with onset during the years of formal schooling. The learning difficulties are not better explained by intellectual disabilities or other conditions.

The collection of conceptual, social, and practical skills that are learned and performed by people in their everyday lives. In DSM-5, deficits in adaptive functioning are central to the diagnosis of intellectual disability and determine how well a person meets community standards of personal independence and social responsibility.

questions.error_original: severity level (mild, moderate, severe, profound) is determined primarily by IQ score ranges rather than adaptive functioning
questions.error_correct: severity level (mild, moderate, severe, profound) is determined primarily by adaptive functioning rather than IQ score ranges
questions.explanation: In DSM-5, a key change from DSM-IV is that intellectual disability severity is now based on adaptive functioning across conceptual, social, and practical domains, not on IQ scores alone. The error reverses this by stating severity is determined by IQ score ranges, which was the older DSM-IV approach.

entries.definition: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting at least 7 days (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary), accompanied by at least three additional symptoms such as grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, or pressured speech.

Five or more symptoms present during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning. At least one symptom must be (1) depressed mood or (2) diminished concentration or indecisiveness (anhedonia).

A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting at least 4 consecutive days, accompanied by at least three additional symptoms that represent a noticeable change in functioning but are not severe enough to cause marked impairment.

A chronic form of depression characterized by depressed mood for most of the day, more days than not, for at least 2 years in adults (1 year in children/adolescents), accompanied by at least two additional depressive symptoms such as poor appetite or low self-esteem.

questions.explanation: The DSM-5 criteria for a Major Depressive Episode require that at least one of the five or more symptoms must be either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia). The error replaces 'loss of interest or pleasure' with 'diminished concentration or indecisiveness,' which is a separate symptom in the MDE criteria but is not one of the two gateway symptoms required for diagnosis.

entries.definition: A DSM-5 specifier for OCD that applies when the individual has a current or past history of a tic disorder. Tic-related OCD is characterized by a later onset, more frequent male predominance, and higher rates of symmetry and ordering compulsions.

A DSM-5 specifier for OCD that characterizes the degree to which the individual recognizes that their OCD beliefs may not be true. It includes three levels: good or fair insight, poor insight, and absent insight/delusional beliefs.

A DSM-5 specifier for Social Anxiety Disorder that applies when the fear is restricted to speaking or performing in public. Individuals with this specifier typically do not fear or avoid non-performance social situations.

A DSM-5 specifier that can be applied to any disorder when panic attacks are present but are not the primary focus of the clinical presentation. It notes the presence of recurrent unexpected surges of intense fear or discomfort.

questions.explanation: Tic-related OCD is characterized by an earlier onset, not a later onset. Research consistently shows that individuals with the tic-related specifier tend to develop OCD symptoms at a younger age compared to those without comorbid tic disorders.
